prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for “tattling” on my boyfriend to his mother
My boyfriend and I have been together for 5 years, and things were great until our daughter was born 6 months ago.

Since then, our relationship has gone down the tubes because he refuses to care for her. He’ll sit on the couch and play video games and he’ll only tend to her while she’s screaming if I tell him to. Even then, unless I’m in the middle of doing something right then, he’ll ask me why I can’t just do it instead. On top of that, he only holds her if I hand her to him while he’s watching tv and she’s calm. He stays up late playing video games but still won’t get her when she cries, so I have to get up with her. We’ve talked about it multiple times, to the extent that I’ve told him I can’t handle it anymore, and he improves for a week and then goes back to his old ways.

I’m honestly considering filing for divorce but tried one last ditch effort. I put the baby in his gaming room and told him I was leaving. In reality, I just went to the gas station because I felt like I couldn’t trust him, and sure enough when I got back the baby was screaming and he was ignoring her. I took a ~10 second video of this and after I comforted the baby, I sent it to his mother with an explanation of what’s going on.

She called him and absolutely reamed him for it and now he’s upset with me for involving his mother and for “taking a video out of context.” I’m at my wits end and will probably leave him at this point, but AITA for sending the video?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author is a woman in a 5-year relationship with her boyfriend. They have a 6-month-old daughter. The problem is that the boyfriend isn't helping with the baby, just plays games, and only takes care of the baby when the author tells him to. The author is really stressed, has talked to him multiple times, and even threatened to leave. Then she decides to put the baby in his room to test him, takes a video of him ignoring the baby, and sends it to his mom. Now the boyfriend is upset with her for involving his mom and taking the video.

First, I need to consider the boyfriend's behavior. Not helping with a newborn is a big deal. New parents need support, especially with a baby who cries a lot. The boyfriend's actions (ignoring the baby, gaming, not helping) could be neglectful. The author is trying to make him take responsibility, which is understandable. She's exhausted, trying to handle everything alone.

Then she stages a situation to test him. She leaves the baby with him and goes to the gas station. When she comes back, he's ignoring the baby again. She records a 10-second video and sends it to his mom. The key here is whether her actions were justified. She might have felt desperate and needed to get his attention, but involving the mother might be seen as overstepping. Some might say she should have handled it without involving the mother, while others might argue that the mother could help intervene.

The mother's reaction is to "ream" him, which means she's very upset. The boyfriend is now upset with the author for involving his mom. The question is whether she was wrong to do that. 

On one hand, she's trying to protect her child and get help. On the other, she might have broken trust by involving his family without discussing it with him first. However, if he's not responding to her requests, maybe she had limited options. Also, the video serves as evidence of his neglect, which could be important for her case if she decides to leave or take legal action.

But in terms of the relationship, she might have crossed a line by not discussing with him first. But considering the stress and the importance of the child's well-being, maybe it's understandable. So, the answer depends on whether the act of tattling was necessary given the circumstances. If she had tried all other options and he still wasn't improving, maybe it's not her fault. Alternatively, if she could have handled it differently, maybe she's at fault. But given that he's not changing, perhaps her actions were justified.
